content:
I'm going to try something new here: I'll talk about some stuff I'm thinking about, and see if anyone has questions or has something to say. If you don't understand what I'm saying, please ask questions! If you know stuff about this topic, I'd like to hear it!

(On other forums I'm getting disappointed with how few people talk about my posts.)

Given a functor F:A→XF : A \to XF:A→X, any object x∈Xx \in Xx∈X has a "homotopy fiber", where an object is an object a∈Aa \in Aa∈A together with an isomorphism α:F(a)→x\alpha: F(a) \to xα:F(a)→x, and a morphism is 'the obvious thing' (explanation available on request).

This is the obvious sort of categorification of when you have a function between sets, any point in the codomain has a 'fiber' or 'inverse image' consisting of all points in the domain that map to it.
I guess more technically this homotopy fiber is the 'isocomma object' of F:A→XF: A \to XF:A→X and G:1→XG: 1 \to XG:1→X, where GGG is the functor that picks out the object XXX.
I'm interested in certain examples these days. Generalizing from these examples we get this:

Suppose you have algebras AAA and BBB over some field and a homomorphism f:A→Bf: A \to Bf:A→B. Then you get adjoint functors between their categories modules AModA\mathsf{Mod}AMod and BModB\mathsf{Mod}BMod: 'restriction along fff'

f∗:BMod→AModf^\ast : B\mathsf{Mod} \to A\mathsf{Mod}f∗:BMod→AMod

and its left adjoint which I guess might be called 'extension along fff'.

f∗:AMod→BModf_* : A\mathsf{Mod} \to B\mathsf{Mod}f∗​:AMod→BMod
This sends any AAA module MMM to the BBB-module B⊗AMB \otimes_A MB⊗A​M where BBB becomes a right AAA-module using f:A→Bf: A \to Bf:A→B.
So what I'm interested in are the homotopy fibers of f∗f^\astf∗ and f∗f_\astf∗​ in some really concrete examples.
The homotopy fiber of f∗f^*f∗ over some AAA-module MMM is intuitively "the category of ways of extending the AAA-module structure on MMM to a BBB-module structure".
The homotopy fiber of f∗f_\astf∗​ is intuitively "the category of ways you can get the BBB-module MMM from extending some AAA-module".
I'm following so far, but isn't there another adjoint that you could add to this picture? Is restriction along f also cocontinuous?
(Specifically, I'm expecting HomA(M,B)\mathrm{Hom}_A(M,B)HomA​(M,B) to provide the right adjoint)
I'm interested by the "explanation available on request" on what is an homotopy fiber.

John Baez said:

The homotopy fiber of f∗f_*f∗​ over some AAA-module MMM is intuitively "the set of ways of extending the AAA-module structure on MMM to a BBB-module structure".

The homotopy fiber of f∗f^\astf∗ is intuitively "the set of ways you can get the BBB-module MMM from extending some AAA-module".

Aren't those reversed?

As a topologist and topos theorist, I'm used to f∗f_*f∗​ denoting a right adjoint of f∗f^*f∗, which as Morgan mentioned also exists here ("coextension of scalars"); I would write f!f_!f!​ for the left adjoint of f∗f^*f∗. I know that algebraic geometers have different conventions; is f∗f_*f∗​ commonly used for extension of scalars?

Anyway, as for your question, the obvious first class of examples that occurs to me is when A=kA=kA=k is the field itself. Then the f∗f^*f∗-fiber over a vector space MMM is the set of BBB-module structures on it.

Mike Shulman said:

John Baez said:

The homotopy fiber of f∗f_*f∗​ over some AAA-module MMM is intuitively "the set of ways of extending the AAA-module structure on MMM to a BBB-module structure".

The homotopy fiber of f∗f^\astf∗ is intuitively "the set of ways you can get the BBB-module MMM from extending some AAA-module".

Aren't those reversed?

Yes, fixed.

Mike Shulman said:

As a topologist and topos theorist, I'm used to f∗f_*f∗​ denoting a right adjoint of f∗f^*f∗, which as Morgan mentioned also exists here ("coextension of scalars"); I would write f!f_!f!​ for the left adjoint of f∗f^*f∗. I know that algebraic geometers have different conventions; is f∗f_*f∗​ commonly used for extension of scalars?

I don't know what the hell different people do with all this f∗,f∗,f!f^\ast, f_\ast, f_!f∗,f∗​,f!​ notation - I find it incredibly confusing. Different people seem to do different things. I'm using f∗f^\astf∗ here because an algebra homomorphism f:A→Bf: A \to Bf:A→B is giving rise to a functor going "backwards", f∗:AMod→BModf^\ast : A\mathsf{Mod} \to B \mathsf{Mod}f∗:AMod→BMod.

(So, we're getting a contravariant functor from some category of algebras to some category of some very nice categories, and when we get everything running really smoothly, perhaps adding some side conditions if necessary, it becomes a contravariant equivalence of bicategories.)

Morgan Rogers (he/him) said:

I'm following so far, but isn't there another adjoint that you could add to this picture? Is restriction along f also cocontinuous?

There probably is another adjoint quite generally, but in fact I'm working with semisimple algebras, whose categories of (finite-dimensional) modules are semisimple categories, and this seems to ensure that the that my left adjoint f∗f_\astf∗​ is also a right adjoint to f∗f^\astf∗. So in my particular context I've got an [[ambidextrous adjunction]], which is very fun but makes it unnecessary to roam the land looking for further adjoints.
I should add that I'm interested in really specific features of really specific examples, so I haven't put much effort into improving my overall understanding of the general theory.

Let me mention an example and pose some puzzles about it. I'm looking at algebras over R\mathbb{R}R. My go-to example of a homomorphism of algebras f:A→Bf: A \to Bf:A→B is the inclusion i:R→Ci: \mathbb{R} \to \mathbb{C}i:R→C.

So, f∗f^\astf∗ gives me the "underlying real vector space of a complex vector space", while f∗f_\astf∗​ gives me the "complexification of a real vector space":

f∗(V)=C⊗RVf_\ast(V) = \mathbb{C} \otimes_{\mathbb{R}} V f∗​(V)=C⊗R​V
f∗(W)={real-linear maps R→W}f^\ast(W) = \{ \text{real-linear maps } \mathbb{R} \to W \} f∗(W)={real-linear maps R→W}

Here's the puzzle:

  1. Given a real vector space VVV, what is the set of isomorphism classes in the homotopy fiber of f∗f^\astf∗ over VVV?

  2. Given a complex vector space WWW, what is the set of isomorphism classes in the homotopy fiber of f∗f_\astf∗​ over WWW?
I'm really just asking for any other, less category-ridden and I hope more easily understood, description of these two sets.
Both these sets are famous (in certain quarters anyway - famous enough to have Wikipedia pages), but they're also fairly easy to describe without knowing any of the known stuff.

Jean-Baptiste Vienney said:

I'm interested by the "explanation available on request" on what is an homotopy fiber.

The short answer is: the homotopy fiber of a functor F:A→XF: A \to XF:A→X over a point xxx is the category of ways you can get xxx (up to isomorphism) by applying the functor FFF to some object of AAA. The "up to isomorphism" part is what makes it a homotopy fiber instead of an ordinary fiber.

In homotopy theory we are often interested in a map F:A→XF: A \to XF:A→X between topological spaces, and then the homotopy fiber of a point x∈Xx \in Xx∈X consists of points a∈Aa \in Aa∈A that don't need to have F(a)=xF(a) = xF(a)=x "on the nose": instead, it's enough to have a continuous path from F(a)F(a)F(a) to xxx.

I hope you see that here we are using an analogy between

  • isomorphisms between objects in categories

and

  • paths between points in spaces.

This analogy is ultimately much more than an analogy, especially if we stick to categories that are just groupoids, or nnn-categories that are nnn-groupoids.
